sections.title: What is the past perfect?
sections.content:
**Past perfect** = **had + past participle** (had gone, had finished, had written).

It describes an action that was **completed before** another past action or before a time in the past.

• Past simple: I **left** at 5. (one past event)
• Past perfect: When I arrived, she **had** already **left**. (she left before I arrived)

Examples: He had finished his homework before dinner. By 2020 they had sold the house.

sections.title: When do we use it?
sections.content:
Use the past perfect when:

• Something happened **before** another past action: When I got home, my sister **had cooked** dinner. (cooking was finished before I got home)
• Something was true **by** a time in the past: By 9 o'clock she **had left**. I **had never been** there before 2020.
• To give **cause or reason** in the past: I was tired because I **hadn't slept** well.

Often used with: **before**, **by the time**, **when** (with past simple in the other clause), **already**, **never**.

sections.title: Form: had + past participle
sections.content:
**Positive:** subject + **had** + past participle — She had gone. They had finished.

**Negative:** subject + **had not (hadn't)** + past participle — He hadn't seen it.

**Question:** **Had** + subject + past participle? — Had you left before 5?

**Past participle:** regular → -ed (finished, opened). Irregular → learnt list (gone, written, seen, left).

sections.title: Past perfect vs past simple
sections.content:
**Two past events:**
• The one that happened **first** → past perfect.
• The one that happened **later** (or is the main focus) → past simple.

When I **arrived** (past simple – main event), the film **had already started** (past perfect – earlier).

If the order is clear from **before** / **after** / **when**, we sometimes use past simple for both: She **left** before I **arrived**. But past perfect is clearer: She **had left** before I arrived.

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• Past perfect = **had** + past participle. Use it for something **before** another past action or **by** a time in the past.
• First past event → past perfect. Second/main event → past simple.
• Typical: By the time..., When I got there..., She had already left. I had never seen it before.

sections.title: Typical errors
sections.content:
• **Using past simple for the earlier action:** Wrong: When I arrived, she *left*. Right: When I arrived, she **had left**.
• **Using had with did:** Wrong: I *had went*. She *had didn't see* it. Right: I **had gone**. She **hadn't seen** it. (No did – had is the auxiliary.)
• **Using past perfect for the main event:** Wrong: She had left when I had arrived. Right: She **had left** when I **arrived**.
• **Overusing past perfect:** If the order is clear (e.g. She left before I arrived), past simple for both is fine.

Tip: Earlier past = had + participle. Later past = past simple.

questions.question: 'When I got there, she _____ home.' (She left before I got there.) Which fits?
questions.explanation: Action before another past action → past perfect.

questions.question: 'By 9 o'clock he _____ his homework.' Which fits?
questions.explanation: By + time in the past → past perfect.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
questions.explanation: Past perfect = had + past participle. Go → gone.

questions.question: 'She was tired because she _____ well.' Which fits?
questions.explanation: Cause in the past (before she was tired) → past perfect.

questions.question: 'When they arrived, the meeting _____.' (The meeting started before they arrived.) Which fits?
questions.explanation: Earlier past action → past perfect.

questions.question: When I got home, my sister _____ (already / go) to bed.
questions.explanation: Earlier past action → past perfect.

questions.question: By 2020 they _____ (sell) the house.
questions.explanation: By + time in the past → past perfect.

questions.question: She _____ (never / be) to Japan before last year.
questions.explanation: Before a past time → past perfect.

questions.question: When I arrived, the film _____ (already / start).
questions.explanation: Earlier past → past perfect.

questions.question: He was angry because someone _____ (take) his bag.
questions.explanation: Cause in the past → past perfect.

questions.question: I _____ (not / see) her before that day.
questions.explanation: Before a past time → past perfect negative.

questions.question: By the time we got to the station, the train _____ (leave).
questions.explanation: By the time + past → past perfect for the earlier action.

questions.question: She _____ (finish) her work before dinner.
questions.explanation: Before another past time → past perfect.

questions.question: _____ you _____ (eat) when they arrived?
questions.explanation: Past perfect question: Had + subject + past participle.

questions.question: We couldn't get in because we _____ (lose) the key.
questions.explanation: Reason in the past → past perfect.

questions.question: Wrong: 'When I arrived, she left.' (She left before I arrived.) Correct the sentence.
answers: When I arrived, she had left.
When I arrived, she had left
questions.explanation: Earlier past action → past perfect (had left).

questions.question: Wrong: 'I had went to London in 2019.' Correct the sentence.
answers: I had gone to London in 2019.
questions.explanation: Past perfect needs past participle: go → gone. Or use past simple for a single past event.

questions.question: Wrong: 'By 8 o'clock she has left.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: By + past time → past perfect (had left), not present perfect.

questions.question: Wrong: 'He was sad because he had didn't pass the exam.' Correct the sentence.
answers: He was sad because he hadn't passed the exam.
He was sad because he hadn't passed the exam
questions.explanation: Past perfect negative: had not (hadn't) + past participle. No 'did'.

questions.question: Wrong: 'When they had arrived, the show had started.' Correct the sentence.
answers: When they arrived, the show had started.
When they arrived, the show had started
questions.explanation: Main past event (they arrived) → past simple. Earlier action (show started) → past perfect.

questions.question: Wrong: 'She had never saw that film before.' Correct the sentence.
answers: She had never seen that film before.
She had never seen that film before
questions.explanation: Past perfect: had + past participle. See → seen.
